message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The swollen and painful toe is likely an acute attack of gout. Indomethacin is the drug of choice for treating acute gout attacks. Aspirin and Rasburicase are not the first-line treatments for gout, and allopurinol is used to prevent recurrent gout attacks, not to treat acute attacks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a swollen and painful toe suggests gout, which is caused by the buildup of uric acid crystals in the joint. Indomethacin is the drug of choice for gout as it is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that reduces inflammation and pain. Aspirin can actually worsen gout symptoms, while rasburicase and allopurinol are used to treat hyperuricemia, which is the underlying cause of gout, but are not the first-line treatment for acute gout attacks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest gout, which is caused by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood. Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that is effective in treating gout attacks by reducing inflammation and pain. Aspirin, Rasburicase, and Allopurinol are not the drugs of choice for acute gout attacks. Aspirin and Allopurinol can even worsen symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest gout, which is caused by uric acid crystals forming in joints due to high levels of uric acid in the bloodstream. Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that is often used to reduce inflammation and pain in the treatment of acute gout attacks. Aspirin can worsen gout by decreasing the urinary excretion of uric acid. Rasburicase and allopurinol are not used in the treatment of acute gout attacks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest gout, which is caused by the buildup of uric acid crystals in the joint. Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can reduce the inflammation and pain associated with gout. Aspirin is not the drug of choice for gout and can actually make it worse. Rasburicase and Allopurinol are used for hyperuricemia, but not for acute gout flares.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest gout, which is caused by the deposition of uric acid crystals in the joint. Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that is the drug of choice for gout treatment. Aspirin can actually worsen gout symptoms, and Rasburicase and Allopurinol are used for the prevention and management of tumor lysis syndrome and chronic gout, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The swollen and painful toe suggest a gout attack. Indomethacin is the drug of choice for treating acute gout attacks. Aspirin, Rasburicase, and Allopurinol are not the preferred initial treatment for gout attacks. Aspirin can actually exacerbate symptoms by increasing uric acid levels. Rasburicase is used for tumor lysis syndrome and Allopurinol is used for chronic gout management, not for acute attacks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest gout, and indomethacin is the drug of choice for treating acute gout attacks. Aspirin can make gout worse, rasburicase is used to treat hyperuricemia in cancer patients, and allopurinol is used for long-term prevention of gout attacks, not for acute treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The swollen and painful toe is most likely gout, and Indomethacin is the drug of choice for acute gout attacks. Aspirin is not recommended as it can increase uric acid levels, and Rasburicase and Allopurinol are used for chronic gout management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest gout, and indomethacin is the drug of choice for treating acute gout attacks by reducing inflammation and pain. Aspirin is not recommended because it can increase the level of uric acid in the blood, exacerbating gout. Rasburicase and allopurinol are used for preventing gout attacks, not for treating acute attacks.
